body:
Hey @epugh I pushed up a few fixes for my previous review comments.

In the process though I noticed something odd.  On certain API calls, the docs still have two sets of examples.  Take `DELETEREPLICA` in `replica-management.adoc` for example.  The section gives a short overview, then has some tabbed v1/v2 examples, then it has detailed description for each API parameter.  All great so far!  But then before the next API command, it gives _more_ DELETEREPLICA examples.

In some cases (e.g. ADDREPLICA) the second set of examples are different enough from the first set that they might provide value.  But in other cases it looks like the two sets of examples are near duplicates and we just forgot to remove them.

Was this something you did thoughtfully?  Or was it just an oversight?  Happy to go through and fix myself - just wanted to make sure I wasn't undoing something you did intentionally.

> Hey @epugh I pushed up a few fixes for my previous review comments.
> 
> In the process though I noticed something odd. On certain API calls, the docs still have two sets of examples. Take `DELETEREPLICA` in `replica-management.adoc` for example. The section gives a short overview, then has some tabbed v1/v2 examples, then it has detailed description for each API parameter. All great so far! But then before the next API command, it gives _more_ DELETEREPLICA examples.
> 
> In some cases (e.g. ADDREPLICA) the second set of examples are different enough from the first set that they might provide value. But in other cases it looks like the two sets of examples are near duplicates and we just forgot to remove them.
> 
> Was this something you did thoughtfully? Or was it just an oversight? Happy to go through and fix myself - just wanted to make sure I wasn't undoing something you did intentionally.

If you are in there, I think go ahead and delete them!   I think I ended up changing the structure to make the v1 and v2 examples always at the top, and then the more detailed down below, that might have caused some duplicates.

your edits look great!   

WDYT about merging after those last edits?  Feel free to click the magic button!

@thelabdude Please have a look at this. I tested in grafana and did an export through "share" button -> export -> "export for sharing externally". But the diff is all messed up, so hard to review.

I might attempt to just copy/paste the changed and added sections. Any hints?

Very cool @janhoy . I imported into a live K8s cluster running 8.8.2 with the customized exporter config and see the attached. Not sure what that extra dimension with `=:` is on the Replica State History panel? Might have a look at that ... It's up now if you want to try it out: http://34.122.167.160:3000/d/yt5eXHbMz5/solr-dashboard-main-fixed?orgId=1&refresh=30s&from=now-5m&to=now (I'll slack you the login creds)

> Not sure what that extra dimension with `=:` is on the Replica State History panel?

Since the state label was not there before, you have historic data points without any value. So if you change to last 15 minutes they will disappear...

Thanks for feedback. Will push a commit with some of the things we discussed on slack.

Pushed changes
* state history is now 0 for active, and any non-active will stack up in the graph. Much easier to spot failures
* hide legends of replicas that have never been shard leader
* change title of the dashboard to "Solr Dashboard"

I rm'd the stuff that looked redundant to me, so I'm fine w/ merging whenever at this point.  I'll leave it open for the weekend to let you do the honors, or in case you want to make sure I wasn't overzealous in ripping out redundancy, but otherwise I'll click the button on Monday.

Thanks for picking this up Eric

I think like Houston, I would prefer to see a bin/somethingelse instead of bin/solr on principle because this is not starting solr, this is starting/installing Zeppelin.  On this point I'm "-0".  Disclaimer I very cursory looked at the diff.

> This file is generated by `grunt build`, do not edit it by hand.

I assume this isn't really the case anymore?

> > This file is generated by `grunt build`, do not edit it by hand.
> 
> I assume this isn't really the case anymore?

this is another "deprecated we don't support it" Angular1 project..   So I wouldn't expect any updates...    On the other hand, maybe this setting should go in another file?   I'm not a CSS person, so not sure how to add that property to another CSS file and leave this one alone....
I tried to add the css to `common.css` to see what that did, and leave `chosen.css` alone, but it didn't seem to work.
Yeah, it was probably auto-generated, then copied into the project. Should be fine...

I am going to leave this PR open for a few days, to see if the original reporter wants to also try and do something with smart CSS to make the collection/core names in the "admin pane" maybe highlight nicely when you mouse over them or something.  If we get that great, otherwise I'll just merge this fix as it's already a helpful change.   (why didn't we do this 5 years ago!)
@dsmiley @dweiss @bruno-roustant  Please review
The ticket number in CHANGES.txt is SOLR-15238, not SOLR-15283.
I have added a new commit which contains the new entry in the CHANGES.txt
Thanks @ryo0301 ; I pushed a fix.
You are tagging people that have not touched this code :-). I tagged @cpoerschke (who does touch it) for review.

> You are tagging people that have not touched this code :-). I tagged @cpoerschke (who does touch it) for review.

Thank you :)
@cpoerschke @ErickErickson @romseygeek @michaelbraun @dweiss Please review
No, please keep these folders separate. If you overlap intellij and gradle outputs things start to look really weird when you're running from the IDE and from command-line at the same time.
In other words - this is an intentional configuration to separate output folders, not an oversight of some sort.

I imagined this was intentional, but didn't quite understand why. I suspect this was working around a bug in an older IntelliJ, maybe.

For my particular install, IntelliJ builds don't even generate these directories, so it's hard to guess the intent behind them.

It depends how you run intellij. Gradle settings window will give you options to compile/run with intellij or via gradle - the default seems to be gradle these days. I prefer IntelliJ's compiler (faster and more reliable). Overlapping output folders cause headaches especially on Windows where two concurrent tools lock files, etc. 

If you really want this you could make it configurable (with the default separating builds) - a conditional on propertyOrDefault("ide.intellij.separateFolders", "true") and then override this setting locally (and document in help/ides.txt).
Can you explain why this only impacts the TLOG and PULL repliacas and doesn't impact regular NRT?   DOn't the periodically pull everything if they get out of sync?

The _PULL_ replica under the hood utilizes the (ancient) replication handler. On the _PULL_ replica side, the `IndexFetcher` is set up programmatically and cannot be configured through the `solrconfig.xml`. It is used to poll the leader for updates as the _PULL_ replica does neither use the transaction log nor gets pushed any updates upon indexing.

_NRT_ replicas do not need to fetch updates frequently from the leader as updates are pushed to the _NRT_ nodes during indexing.

I was having some trouble with flakiness in GCSIncrementalBackupTest, but I just found the concurrency issue (caused by the  FakeStorageRpc test library).  With these tests passing I'll look to merge this afternoon!

Thanks for the reviews guys!

> NRT replicas do not need to fetch updates frequently from the leader as updates are pushed to the NRT nodes during indexing.

If I understand this correctly, then an NRT replica coming up new would also encounter this issue?

I'm not entirely comfortable with adding another username/password through system properties or environment variables. More places for something to get leaked.

Why isn't PKI Authentication handling this internode communication?
Thanks @madrob for jumping in, I think you asked the question that I was struggling to articulate!

Thanks for the review @madrob . The issue occurs in https://github.com/apache/solr/blob/main/solr/solrj/src/java/org/apache/solr/client/solrj/impl/BaseCloudSolrClient.java#L1095 when SolrJ tries to identiy a path as admin or not. I wonder why we compare with a hard-coded set of absolute paths instead of doing pattern matching, e.g. `request.getPath().startsWith("/admin/")`? The `/solr/admin/*` path is reserved for admin, there cannot be a core/collection named "admin", can there?

@madrob andy thoughts?
Solved the conflict caused by SOLR-15329. @janhoy can you please check it.
Would it be appropriate to provide pointers to Apache ManifoldCF and Apache Nutch projects in this context? Also perhaps link to RefGuide pages about SolrJ indexing and other clients?

Maybe reference a "related projects page" (wiki maybe?) that has a section for indexing data. I do now notice that the first page of the indexing section does say something about not using command line tools, but guides like this are often not read cover to cover.

Agree. What's the difference between web/favicon.ico and web/img/favicon.ico? Can one be deleted?
There is also a favicon in `solr/solr-ref-guide/src/images/icons/favicon.ico`, can you update that as well? And I guess there's one in the solr-site git repo as well, for the website?

> Do we really need all command endpoints in this one class, which I believe is your intention to do?

That was my intention, yep - based mostly on how I read the existing convention with these files.  But I'm not strongly attached to that or anything.

If we put the API logic itself in these files, then I definitely agree that each command would benefit from its own file.  But we're pretty far from that right now - right now FooAPi is just v2->v1 conversion logic.  And in the current form I think the "by path" grouping is reasonable.  Or at the very least, it does no harm.

So I'm ambivalent currently.  If you feel strongly that each of these gets its own class, and you think there's benefits to that even before we split up the CollectionsHandler logic, then I'm open to going that route.

I worry about recommending any specific solution, because there are so many out there.   Haven't we tried to build a list of related projects before?   I tried to find it on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/collector/pages.action?key=SOLR and didn't.   Maybe it's time to try and create that list again?

Makes sense. I decided that the Structure101 plugin wasn't worth it anyway, because it was having issues linking the byte code to the source code so lost a lot of power that way. Instead of changing the paths, I'll document more about the logic, hopefully somebody in the future will save themselves some time.

There is no difference between web/favicon.ico and web/img/facicon.ico. We can definitely replace web/img/favicon.ico with the modern favicon.ico and delete web/favicon.ico while updating references. I'll update them all and link the new PR here. I'll also do it for the solr-site repo as well
@epugh I had the same memory and a similar search experience
the message you added @gus-asf does convey the point of the tool!
Thanks. And sorry for not being explicit in the build sometimes - some fragments are copy-pasted from my other projects and I didn't document them properly.

@janhoy I've deleted web/favicon.ico (that had no references anyway), and updated solr/solr-ref-guide/src/images/icons/favicon.ico. I've also made a PR for the website:
https://github.com/apache/solr-site/pull/21

> Several commits here are not about Rawtypes warnings and thus should be separated.

unchecked casts go hand in hand with raw types so I’m not splitting those out. The zoo thread null check can be left out, sure. Is there more?

> unchecked casts go hand in hand with raw types so I’m not splitting those out.

100% agree; I didn't mean to suggest otherwise!

An example: TestDistribPackageStore.assertResponseValues felt out of place.  Maybe there are others.  I was expecting this PR just to be about types/casts to remove some warnings.  Thanks for this!

That’s a bug I found because I changed an unchecked makeMap to map.of somewhere, so iteration order changed and I discovered that we were only asserting the first value in the map.

Sometimes when you remove warnings you find real bugs! If this wasn’t the case, I wouldn’t spend time on it.
@janhoy whats the status of this?
See the linked Jira. I plan to commit in a day or two, barring any other comments.
Going to watch the new unit test in nightlies before back-porting to 8.x
As I mentioned in the previous PR @madrob, the TestPullReplica is flaky when beasting so I left it with AwaitsFix.

This is the test that is flaky (failed after 14 successful runs):
```
  2> 51776 INFO  (qtp480337175-304) [n:127.0.0.1:56516_solr     ] o.a.s.s.HttpSolrCall [admin] webapp=null path=/admin/collections params={name=pull_replica_test_kill_leader&action=DELETE&wt=javabin&version=2} status=0 QTime=117
  2> 51776 INFO  (TEST-TestPullReplica.testKillLeader-seed#[5929A53F160DEFEC]) [n:127.0.0.1:56516_solr     ] o.a.s.c.TestPullReplica Collection deleted
  2> 51776 INFO  (TEST-TestPullReplica.testKillLeader-seed#[5929A53F160DEFEC]) [n:127.0.0.1:56516_solr     ] o.a.s.SolrTestCaseJ4 ###Ending testKillLeader
   >     java.lang.AssertionError: Replica core_node4 not up to date after 30 seconds expected:<1> but was:<0>
   >         at __randomizedtesting.SeedInfo.seed([5929A53F160DEFEC:103F518B74B67BBA]:0)
   >         at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:89)
   >         at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:835)
   >         at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:647)
   >         at org.apache.solr.cloud.TestPullReplica.waitForNumDocsInAllReplicas(TestPullReplica.java:545)
   >         at org.apache.solr.cloud.TestPullReplica.waitForNumDocsInAllReplicas(TestPullReplica.java:532)
   >         at org.apache.solr.cloud.TestPullReplica.doTestNoLeader(TestPullReplica.java:403)
   >         at org.apache.solr.cloud.TestPullReplica.testKillLeader(TestPullReplica.java:307)
```
Re-running the test with the given seed it passes, so something flaky in there ...

I think it looks better. I suppose you can add some RefGuide edits as well as part of this PR? and a CHANGES entry.

Q: Do we really need an ORANGE level? The traffic light analogy is well understood, i.e. what would smashing together yellow and orange to yellow really lose? If you were an OPS person, would you not take a YELLOW warning alarm in Slack just as seriously as an ORANGE one? You know the system is running but needs attention to become GREEN again...

Sure, I'll write the docs / CHANGES before merging.

The reason I added ORANGE is that it conveys a much greater sense of urgency than YELLOW - it's quite possible to temporarily lose individual replicas when a host/pod goes down and is being replaced. Anything short of 100% would trigger a YELLOW state but it might not be as urgent as ORANGE, when you know for sure that something bad is happening.

Alternatively, we could slightly relax the GREEN state to allow for eg. 95% replicas online, but this feels like cheating... ;)

The `TestPullReplica` class, with a few minor changes (mainly re-querying every 200ms vs. 100ms, which shouldn't change test logic, but no need to loop that fast esp. when waiting up to 30 secs), passes 30/30 locally but I'm still not sure there isn't some weird race still as I've seen failures in `testAddDocs` and `testKillLeader` when beast'ing. But the way I see it, it's better to re-enable this test and get some information instead of leaving it disabled.

I'm a bit perplexed by my failure to reference another page correctly.
```
Relative link points at id that doesn't exist in dest: query-settings-in-solrconfig.html#filterCache
 ... source: file:/home/runner/work/solr/solr/solr/solr-ref-guide/build/local-jdoc-links-site/common-query-parameters.html
```

@ctargett maybe you see something I don't?
Also, please let me know what you think of the changes generally.

I think it's the casing of the link reference - try `...#filtercache`. 

Sometimes when I'm struggling with this, I look at the page I'm trying to refer to after it's been built. For example in this case, you can see the anchor in the HTML is all lower-case, as in: `https://nightlies.apache.org/solr/draft-guides/solr-reference-guide-main/query-settings-in-solrconfig.html#filtercache`

I tried to plot all the percentages and colors for a 1..10 replica cluster. I find it a bit odd that for a 3-node cluster you go to ORANGE straight away even if 2 out of 3 replicas are working. I also find it strange to go to RED while you still have one working replica? Any opinion on the ORANGE level @thelabdude or @dsmiley ?

I think this is ready for review/merge.  I'll may wait for more internal use where I work before merging.  The V2 API doesn't result in ideal span operation names (looks like `post:/c/collection1` instead of `create:/c/{collection}`, however, and I think that should come in a separate PR that follows some of the work in #81 which will likely affect the approach on how to solve it.
Here is my much simpler proposal :)
Yes I do feel strongly that they get their own class.  That solves your naming conundrum :-)

I could go either way but seeing your simpler proposal, seems like a lot of
yellow but there really is a difference from 90% of my replicas being up
and only 10%! So what if we reserve orange for <20% of replicas up? That
would at least differentiate some of the yellow with what I would consider
a really bad situation in the cluster even though it is still serving some
traffic.

On Wed, May 5, 2021 at 2:22 PM Jan Høydahl ***@***.***> wrote:

> Here is my much simpler proposal :)
> [image: Skjermbilde 2021-05-05 kl 22 21 03]
> <https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/409128/117204187-479a8f80-adf0-11eb-885a-a877673e458a.png>
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/solr/pull/73#issuecomment-832981639>, or
> unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AADF2MQXFRI4OGEPEQQZ3ZTTMGSIZANCNFSM42ZSFYFQ>
> .
>

If orange is "You should look at this", then <30/33% probably seems like a good number. If you have 6 replicas, 2/6 alive would be a "You need to look at this now, things are not looking good" sort of scenario.

- Red: 0% (or no-write?)
- Orange: 1-33%
- Yellow: 33%-99%
- Green: 100%
+1 to Houston's proposal.  Thanks everyone for putting time into this!

Thanks for input. Here is Houston's proposal in the sheet:
![Skjermbilde 2021-05-06 kl  09 40 47](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/409128/117260312-3af95400-ae4f-11eb-9b72-fa4b078af2a5.png)
(The sheet is here https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/117R33zSFb10D5Jq5agOrgC7nMv74mQmiLssmLk_6YkA/edit?usp=sharing if you want to experiment. Go to Format->Conditional formatting to change rules)

If we are to distinguish between yellow and orange, I think Houston's proposal makes more sense. I.e. for a 3-replica collection you go yellow when losing one replica and orange when only 1/3 is left. And OPS people who are easily scared can always setup warn alarms for situations where YELLOW state persists for several minutes. For a 2-replica collection, you could argue that losing 50% of the replicas and having only one left warrants orange since you're down with only one failure. Setting orange 1-50% and yellow 51-99% would account for that?
@janhoy the 1-50 and 51-99 thresholds make sense to me. I'll change the PR accordingly.

Just for the record, here is how the levels distribute with the new 0% and 50% thresholds:
![Skjermbilde 2021-05-06 kl  15 18 36](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/409128/117304738-5cbdff80-ae7e-11eb-848f-d44c0bcfb9a2.png)
It is clear that you always tolerate one replica being bounced at a time without going ORANGE, except for the 2-replica case, which I guess makes total sense.

Thanks Andrzej!
Merged.
Thanks all for the comments and suggestions!
Do you still need the branch @sigram?
If I could be of help, then assign me to do one of the commands and I'll push to your PR.

thanks @gerlowskija 

other than the class name it looks fine

> QueryMatchers could probably go into Lucene, but we're separate projects now so c'est la vie

Could it not go into the lucene test-framework jar?

Sorry, I'd put this on my TODO list for this week but didn't say so here, only on the JIRA ticket.

Thanks @alessandrobenedetti for also taking a look!

I agree it makes sense to remove the recursion in the `score` method if that improves latency. Any thoughts on also removing recursion in the `explain` method, since they are related and then would follow the same approach?

>  removing recursive calls kinda defeats the meaning of having the RegressionNode to have the score method, potentially only the root needs that, anyway it just a consideration, ...

And not having the method would also remove the potential for implementation mishaps such as `threshold` i.e. `this.threshold` being used instead of `regressionTreeNode.threshold` in the loop, or for code readers to need to consider that those three possibilities exist. Added a commit to try this out, feel free to revert or adapt. What do you think?

> > QueryMatchers could probably go into Lucene, but we're separate projects now so c'est la vie
> 
> Could it not go into the lucene test-framework jar?

It probably does belong in the lucene test-frameworks, but I really don't want to go through the dance of commit to lucene, wait for snapshot to propagate up to solr, work on test fixes in solr, commit updated matchers to lucene, etc. Once this issue is done, we can talk about porting them over to Lucene?
Thanks!  Going to merge.

Hmm, I just tried to merge in the latest `origin/main` and add the `solr/CHANGES.txt` entry before merging here but then github wouldn't let me push the commits to the pull request branch.

@tboeghk would you be comfortable enabling maintainers [access](https://help.github.com/en/articles/allowing-changes-to-a-pull-request-branch-created-from-a-fork) for this PR branch? Or could I ask you to add the `solr/CHANGES.txt` entry e.g. something like

```
* SOLR-15377: Improve IndexFetcher's exception logging upon replication errors. (Torsten Bøgh Köster, Christine Poerschke)
```

in (say) the "Other Changes" sub-section of the  8.9.0 section? Thanks!
The correct solution for this issue is in this PR: https://github.com/apache/solr/pull/112. Let's not merge this one please.

Unfortunately this  PR originated from an organizational fork and not from a personal repo, so I cannot enable access for maintainers ([bug in Github](https://github.com/isaacs/github/issues/1681)). 

But I happily added the change to `solr/CHANGES.txt`!
I close this PR in favor of #112. That is the correct and best solution for the problem.
Did you use anything from Torsten Bøgh Köster repro case on #100 ? If so, please include him credited in the CHANGES.

> Unfortunately this PR originated from an organizational fork and not from a personal repo, so I cannot enable access for maintainers ([bug in Github](https://github.com/isaacs/github/issues/1681)).

Ah, interesting, thanks for sharing!

> But I happily added the change to `solr/CHANGES.txt`!

Thank you.

Hi @alessandrobenedetti  and @cpoerschke 

Really thanks for reviewing this.  Have added an entry in CHANGES.txt and made the same recursion to loop changes for explain and validate methods as well.

> > removing recursive calls kinda defeats the meaning of having the RegressionNode to have the score method, potentially only the root needs that, anyway it just a consideration, ...
> 
> And not having the method would also remove the potential for implementation mishaps such as `threshold` i.e. `this.threshold` being used instead of `regressionTreeNode.threshold` in the loop, or for code readers to need to consider that those three possibilities exist. Added a commit to try this out, feel free to revert or adapt. What do you think?

Makes sense to keep like this to avoid errors coming because of this. vs regressionTreeNode. Followed the same approach in validate and explain methods
I'm going to watch how the TestPullReplica test does on Jenkins today before back-porting to 8x. It's passing in local beasting but I still see the random fail out of 60 runs or so ...

I ser you have double set of legends. Probably because of some label differences? 

I have not tested any of this with standalone solr, do you know a way to disable a grafana row conditionally if we are not in cloud mode?

> Makes sense to keep like this to avoid errors coming because of this. vs regressionTreeNode. Followed the same approach in validate and explain methods

Good catch about `validate` also having recursion, thanks @suryakant261 for including that in the PR iteration!
Hmm, running locally the tests don't pass for me via `./gradlew -p solr/contrib/ltr test` command. The pull request CI does not automatically run these tests.
In light of the comments I'm closing this as Won't Do.

I already have some ideas in mind and will start to improve the code next thing tomorrow morning.

Hi @cpoerschke 
1. Done using iterative preorder traversal.
2. All the test cases passing in the local run now. (Wasn't aware that these are not part of Pull requests build, should we enable it?)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12580992/118318088-86c69000-b516-11eb-835f-9021a6cbac89.png)

the pull request has been updated with what I believe it is the current correct behavior:
/*
     * sow=true implies the minimum should match is "per document"
     * i.e a document to be a match must contain all the mm query terms anywhere at least once
     * sow=false implies the minimum should match is "per field"
     * i.e a document to be a match must contain all the mm query terms in a single field at least once
* */
@janhoy do you want to merge? If not, I'll update the changes entry and merge it later this week.

Hi @cpoerschke ,
Could you please take a look, all the suggested changes are done with unit tests passing locally.

> Gradle Precommit / gradle precommit w/ Java 11 (pull_request)

This failed on the pull request here but succeeded locally, hmm. I will optimistically proceed to merge here and then watch out for any issues after merge before cherry-picking from `solr/main` to `lucene-solr/branch_8x` branch likely tomorrow.
I looked over through the other PR and didn't see usage of var, can you help me find use cases where you think this is helpful.

I removed the "var" usages in the other PR at this particular commit: https://github.com/apache/solr/pull/115/commits/8c9e262401589d15a5260d0a25cf54934507b3a8
We can keep avoiding "var" for longer if we want; I'm not passionate about this.
